Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Learning to Read a Second Language: Neural Basis and Individual Variations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Learning to read one or more foreign languages is essential for social and economic success in this era of globalization. Decades of research have provided much insight into the cognitive and neural mechanisms of reading, especially native-language reading. Less is known, however, about how the brain associates the words we see with their pronunciations when we learn a new language. With support from the National Science Foundation, Dr. Chuansheng Chen (University of California, Irvine) and Dr. Zhong-Lin Lu (University of Southern California), will probe this issue through an innovative design with an artificial language based on written Korean. This collaboration, which also includes researchers at Beijing Normal University, will use functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to map the neural networks of two types of reading: "sounding it out" (known as "assembled phonology") or memorizing the pronunciation of the whole word without sounding out syllable by syllable (known as "addressed phonology"). First, the (most likely distinct) neural networks for the two types of reading will be identified. Second, how these neural networks differ across people speaking different native languages (e.g., alphabetical English vs. logographic Chinese) will be studied. Third, behavioral, neuroanatomical, and neurofunctional measures will be used to predict individual differences in learning to read a new language.

This project will provide solid empirical evidence for the fundamental neural bases of learning to read in a second language. Results from this study will greatly advance our understanding of the neural basis of reading, with major implications for developing more efficient second language learning programs and reading difficulty interventions. The proposed study will also provide many training opportunities for both US and Chinese graduate students and junior researchers to gain experience in international collaboration.

Project Outcomes Report

 

Collaborative Research: Learning to read a second language: cultural constraints and individual variations

Learning to read one or more foreign languages is essential for social and economic success in this era of globalization. Although research on bilinguals has provided much insight into the cognitive and neural representations of native (L1) and second (L2) languages in the bilingual brain, questions remain regarding on the neural correlates of learning to read a second language, the interaction between L1 and L2, and the ways to facilitate L2 learning. In this project, we used a long-term artificial language training paradigm and a short-term online practice paradigm to address those questions.

First, we adopted an innovative artificial language training paradigm to explore the neural bases of addressed and assembled phonologies. Addressed phonology and assembled phonology have been identified as two distinct routes of phonological access (a key component of reading). For assembled phonology, visual words are transformed into phonology through grapheme-to-phoneme correspondences, whereas addressed phonology relies on direct associations between the visual forms of words and their sounds. Previous studies using natural language materials were often confounded by factors such as material familiarity, orthography, and phonology (e.g., alphabetic language vs. logographic language, irregular words vs. regular words). In the current project, we developed an artificial language (based on Korean Hangul) that can be read through either addressed or assembled phonology. Comparison between the two types of learning revealed a clear disassociation between addressed phonology and assembled phonology, i.e., addressed phonology relied more on the ventral pathway (i.e., the bilateral middle temporal gyrus), whereas assembled phonology depended more on the dorsal pathway (i.e., the left precentral gyrus and supramarginal gyrus).

Second, we examined the interactions between L1 and L2 in terms of neural mechanisms. On the one hand, cognitive and neural mechanisms of reading in L2 are modulated by prior language experience (i.e., L1). Behaviorally, compared with native Chinese speakers, native English speakers learned assembled phonology better because of their prior experience to alphabetic language (i.e., English). Consistent with this, native English speakers showed more activations in the left supramarginal gyrus (a key region for assembled phonology) than native Chinese speakers when processing assembled phonology. On the other hand, word reading in L1 is also affected by L2 learning. Specifically, neural activities in the typical reading network decreased even after a short period (eight days) of L2 learning. Furthermore, the effect of L2 on L1 occurred after semantic learning, but not after phonological learning, suggesting L1 and L2 share a common semantic system.

Finally, we explored the ways to facilitate L2 learning. In a series of studies, we compared the efficiency of two types of learning (spaced vs. massed) and examined their neural mechanisms. Our results showed that spaced learning enhanced subsequent recognition memory of novel words by reducing the neural repetition suppression in the left fusiform cortex during learning. Using cortical pattern similarity analysis, we found that better memory can be achieved by reinstating the same neural representation across multiple exposures, but not by creating multiple memory traces. Furthermore, the cortical pattern similarity could make a unique contribution to successful memory even after controlling for the effect of cortical activity, suggesting that one possible mechanism of cortical activity’s effect on episodic memory is the enhancement of pattern similarity.
